questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and lower abdominal tenderness. Digital rectal examination reveals a normal prostate. Urine microscopy shows plenty of pus cells, but no organisms are detected on culture. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sterile pyuria

 

The clinical presentation describes a patient with recurrent urinary tract infections, lower abdominal tenderness, normal prostate examination, and urine culture showing pus cells but no visible organisms. This constellation of findings is characteristic of sterile pyuria.

 

Sterile pyuria occurs when there are white blood cells (pus cells) in the urine but no organisms are visible on standard urine culture. The most common cause of sterile pyuria is Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Chlamydia is an intracellular organism that cannot be seen on routine urine culture, hence the term "sterile" pyuria. This organism is the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) and presents with urinary symptoms and pyuria without visible organisms on standard culture methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute prostatitis: The question specifically states that prostate examination was normal, ruling out both acute and chronic prostatitis.

 

Option B. Granulomatous disease: Granulomatous diseases would typically present with additional features like epithelioid cells, granuloma formation, or necrosis, none of which are mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Chronic prostatitis : Again, the normal prostate examination rules out prostatitis (both acute and chronic forms).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sterile pyuria (pus cells in urine without visible organisms on culture) is commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, the leading cause of non-gonococcal urethritis.

questions.text: A scientist is culturing a virus using the RT-PCR technique and performs 26 amplification cycles. After how many cycles would the DNA quantity be approximately half of what is present at the 26th cycle? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 25

 

In PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction), each cycle doubles the amount of DNA present. This means that after each cycle, the DNA quantity increases exponentially according to the formula 2(n), where n is the number of cycles.

 

After 26 cycles, the amount of DNA = 2(26)

 

To find when the DNA amount would be half of that observed at the 26th cycle:

 

  • Half of 2(26) = ½ x 2(26) = 2-1 × 226 = 225

 

Therefore, after 25 cycles, the amount of DNA would be exactly half of what is observed at the 26th cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In PCR, each cycle doubles the DNA amount; therefore, to get half the DNA amount from cycle n, you need cycle (n-1).

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

choices.text: 1, 3 and 4
1, 2 and 4
2, 3 and 4

questions.text:
Which of the following method of disinfection and sterilization can also kill spores? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Glutaraldehyde
  2. Ethylene oxide
  3. Pasteurization
  4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4

 

Glutaraldehyde, Ethylene oxide, and Ortho-phthalaldehyde are effective methods of disinfection and sterilization that can kill spores.

 

1. Glutaraldehyde: This chemical is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It is known for its compatibility with a variety of medical instruments. However, it requires activation and produces irritant fumes, which are notable disadvantages. Despite these drawbacks, glutaraldehyde is commonly recommended for the disinfection of fibroscopes and respiratory equipment due to its efficacy against spores and other microorganisms.

 

2. ETO (Ethylene oxide) inactivates all microorganisms although bacterial spores (especially B. atrophaeus) are more resistant than other microorganisms. For this reason B. atrophaeus is the recommended biological indicator. ETO is used in healthcare facilities to sterilize critical items (and sometimes semicritical items) that are moisture or heat sensitive and cannot be sterilized by steam sterilization like syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves. Bacillus atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilis are used as sterilization control.

 

4. Ortho-phthalaldehyde: Similar to glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde is a broad-spectrum microbicidal and sporicidal agent. It does not require activation and does not produce irritating fumes, which are significant advantages. However, it is costly and can stain medical equipment. It is often used as an alternative to glutaraldehyde for disinfecting scopes.

 

Other Options

 

3. Pasteurization or pasteurization is a process of food preservation in which packaged and non-packaged foods (such as milk and fruit juices) are treated with mild heat, usually to less than 100 °C (212 °F), to eliminate pathogens and extend shelf life. It has no sporicidal activity and kills non-spore-forming bacteria like Mycobacteria, Brucella, and Salmonella. There are two methods-

 

  1. Holder method -  milk is heated at either 63°C for 30 minutes. Coxiella burnetii is relatively heat resistant and may survive the holder method.
  2. Flash method - milk is heated at 72°C for 15-20 seconds followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure in the slide given below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sclerotic body

 

The histopathological picture shows brown coloured thick walled round cells that have transverse septations within them. These are called as Sclerotic bodies, also known as muriform cells or Medlar bodies, or copper penny appearance a found in tissue biopsies of patients with chromoblastomycosis. These bodies are a key diagnostic feature of this fungal infection.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Budding yeast: This is a general term for yeast cells reproducing through budding. It is not pathognomonic for a specific disease without further context.

 

Option C. Negri bodies are intracytoplasmic, round purplish structures with basophilic inner granules. They are pathognomic of rabies.

 

 

Option D. Asteroid bodies are oval, basophilic structure with eosinophilic radiation. They are antigen-antibody complexes deposits. Seen in sporotricosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Few Important Pathognomonic structures associated with disease:

choices.text: Rickettsia rickettsii
Rickettsia conorii
Anaplasma phagocytophilum

questions.text: The inclusion body Rickettsial morula is found in neutrophils during infection caused by? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anaplasma phagocytophilum

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum is a bacterium known to cause the disease tick-borne fever (TBF) in domestic ruminants in Ixodes ricinus-infested areas in northern Europe. This organism infects granulocytes, particularly neutrophils, leading to the formation of characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies known as morulae.

 

During an infection with Anaplasma phagocytophilum, light microscopy of blood smears taken in the initial fever period can often suffice for diagnosis. When these blood smears are stained with May-Grünwald Giemsa, the organisms appear as blue cytoplasmic inclusions within the neutrophils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickettsia rickettsii: This bacterium causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever, which does not typically involve the formation of morulae in neutrophils. Instead, it causes endothelial cell infection leading to vasculitis.

 

Option B. Rickettsia conorii: The causative agent of Mediterranean spotted fever, also does not typically form morulae in neutrophils. Like R. rickettsii, it primarily infects endothelial cells.

 

Option D. Ehrlichia chaffeensis: This bacterium causes human monocytic ehrlichiosis (HME) and forms morulae in monocytes, not neutrophils. This distinguishes it from Anaplasma phagocytophilum, which targets neutrophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaplasma phagocytophilum causes the formation of Rickettsial morulae in neutrophils, whereas Ehrlichia chaffeensis forms morulae in monocytes.

 

Mnemonic "GAME": Granulocytes: Anaplasma; Monocytes: Ehrlichiosis.

choices.text: Cytotoxic T cells
B cells
NK cells
Helper cells

questions.text: Antigen binding to MHC class I activates which of the following cells? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cytotoxic T cells

 

Cytotoxic T cells: MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, typically derived from intracellular proteins, to cytotoxic T cells (also known as CD8+ T cells). When a cytotoxic T cell recognizes an antigen presented by MHC class I on the surface of a cell, it is activated to destroy the infected or malignant cell.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. B cells: B cells are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) and by direct interaction with helper T cells (CD4+ T cells), not by MHC class I.

 

Option C. NK cells: Natural Killer (NK) cells do not rely on MHC class I molecules for activation. In fact, they often target cells with low or absent MHC class I expression, which is a common strategy of infected or transformed cells to evade cytotoxic T cells.

 

Option D. Helper cells: Helper T cells (CD4+ T cells) are activated by antigens presented by MHC class II molecules on APCs, not by MHC class I.

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: Sporothrix schenckii
Staphylococcus aureus
Nocardia asteroides

questions.text: A young man presents with skin lesions as shown in the image below. All of the following organisms can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus aureus

 

Although Staphylococcus aureus can cause various skin infections, including cellulitis, abscesses, and impetigo, it does not typically spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics in the characteristic pattern of lymphocutaneous spread. Staphylococcus aureus usually causes localized infections.

 

Other Options

 

Organisms that can spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics:

 

Option A. Sporothrix schenckii: Causes sporotrichosis, also known as "rose gardener's disease," which presents with nodular lymphangitis, characterized by lesions following the lymphatic drainage.

 

Option C. Nocardia asteroides: Nocardiosis can present with cutaneous and subcutaneous lesions that spread along lymphatics, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium marinum: Causes swimming pool granuloma or fish tank granuloma, presenting with skin lesions that spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective

 

While Sporothrix schenckii, Nocardia asteroides, and Mycobacterium marinum are known to spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics, causing lymphocutaneous lesions, Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized skin infections and does not exhibit this pattern of spread.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

choices.text: E1, E2, E5
E6, E7
L1, L2

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E6, E7

 

The image shows the life cycle of the human papilloma virus, and the E6 and E7 proteins act as oncogenes

 

 

  • HPV oncogenes E6 and E7 deregulate host cell cycle by binding and inactivating tumor suppressor genes p53 and pRb.
  • Binding of E6 gene to p53 causes degradation of p53.
  • E7 gene binds to pRb and disrupts the complex between pRb and E2F leading to uncontrolled proliferation. HPV, human papilloma virus.

 

 

 

Educational Objective

 

  • E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Only

 

The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive Aspergillosis

 

Galactomannan (GM) belongs to a group of polysaccharides which consist of a mannose backbone and a variable number of galactofuran side chains. GM makes up a major part of the cell wall of Aspergillus spp. These galactofuranose-containing polysaccharides vary are secreted in vivo by the fungus during invasive growth. In recent years, the detection of galactofuranose-containing antigens, including GM, has been used for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA).

 

The most commonly used method to determine GM in serum and broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is a double sandwich enzyme-linked immune assay

 

Other Fungal Infections:

 

2. Systemic Candidiasis: Does not typically involve the release of galactomannan.

 

3. Mucormycosis: Caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, which do not produce  galactomannan. It has beta-D-Glucans and mannans that can be used for diagnosis of invasive candidiasis.

 

4. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus species, and the detection of its polysaccharide capsule antigen (cryptococcal antigen) is used for diagnosis, not galactomannan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galactomannan assay is specifically used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, and the presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of this fungal infection.

questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is associated with Acute Rheumatic Fever? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Type II

 

Explanation:

 

Acute Rheumatic Fever is associated with Type II hypersensitivity reaction. Type II hypersensitivity is antibody-mediated cytotoxic hypersensitivity where antibodies directly bind to antigens on cell surfaces. In Rheumatic Fever, antibodies produced against streptococcal antigens cross-react with self-antigens on heart tissue due to molecular mimicry between streptococcal M protein and human heart tissue antigens. This cross-reactivity leads to immune-mediated damage to heart valves and myocardium. The mnemonic "MBIRH Positive" for Type II reactions specifically includes Rheumatic fever among its examples.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Type I - This is immediate hypersensitivity (anaphylactic/atopic) mediated by IgE antibodies bound to mast cells and basophils. Examples include asthma, hay fever, and anaphylactic shock, not Rheumatic Fever.

 

  • Option C. Type III - This involves immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity where antigen-antibody complexes deposit in tissues, activate complement, and cause inflammation. Examples include serum sickness and Arthus reaction, not Rheumatic Fever.

 

  • Option D. Type IV - This is delayed-type hypersensitivity mediated by T cells rather than antibodies. Examples include contact dermatitis, tuberculin reaction, and transplant rejection, not Rheumatic Fever.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rheumatic Fever exemplifies Type II hypersensitivity where antibodies against streptococcal antigens cross-react with heart tissue due to molecular mimicry, causing immune-mediated cardiac damage.

questions.text: Match the following parasites with their respective hosts: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

  • Diphyllobothrium latum: Humans (definitive host), Cyclops (first intermediate host), and Fish (second intermediate host).
  • Paragonimus westermani: Humans (definitive host), Snail (first intermediate host), Crayfish and Crab (second intermediate host).
  • Brugia malayi: Humans (definitive host), Mansonia mosquito (intermediate host).
  • Fasciola hepatica: Sheep and Humans (definitive hosts), Snail (first intermediate host), Aquatic vegetation (second intermediate host).

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: Which intradermal test is employed for diagnosing Bartonella? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Foshay Test

 

Explanation:

The Foshay test is the specific intradermal skin test used to diagnose Bartonella henselae infections (cat-scratch disease). This skin test produces a positive reaction in patients with cat-scratch disease, providing a useful diagnostic tool in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphogranuloma Venereum Test - This is incorrect because the LGV test (Frei test) is used specifically for diagnosing Lymphogranuloma Venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3, not Bartonella infections.

 

Option C. Leishmania Test - This is incorrect because the Leishmania skin test (Montenegro test) is used to diagnose Leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania species, not Bartonella infections.

 

Option D. Schistosomiasis Test - This is incorrect because intradermal tests for Schistosomiasis detect a different pathogen entirely and are not relevant for Bartonella diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bartonella infections (cat-scratch disease) are diagnosed using the Foshay test, which is a specific intradermal skin test that helps identify this infection in immunocompetent individuals.

questions.text: What must be present in the substrate when performing a Kovac's test? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Tryptophan

 

Explanation:

 

Tryptophan must be present in the substrate when performing a Kovac's test. This test detects the ability of bacteria to produce indole from tryptophan. When bacteria possess the enzyme tryptophanase, they can break down tryptophan to produce indole, pyruvic acid, and ammonia. Kovac's reagent reacts with the produced indole to form a red-colored compound at the top of the test tube. 

 

 

Organisms showing a positive indole tests are: Escherichia coli, Proteus vulgaris, Klebsiella oxytoca etc 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hippurate - Hippurate is the substrate used in the hippurate hydrolysis test, which detects the presence of the enzyme hippuricase. This test is commonly used to differentiate group B streptococci from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, not for indole detection.

 

Option B. Ornithine - Ornithine is the substrate in ornithine decarboxylase test, which detects the enzyme ornithine decarboxylase. This test is part of the panel used to differentiate various Enterobacteriaceae, but is not related to the Kovac's test.

 

Option D. Indole - Indole is the end product detected by Kovac's reagent, not the substrate that must be present initially. Bacteria produce indole from tryptophan; indole itself is not the substrate for the test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kovac's test is fundamentally a test for the enzyme tryptophanase, which converts tryptophan to indole. The test is positive when Kovac's reagent (p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde in amyl alcohol) reacts with indole to produce a red-colored compound.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produce urease? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Helicobacter pylori

 

Helicobacter pylori is well-known for its ability to produce urease, an enzyme that catalyzes the hydrolysis of urea into carbon dioxide and ammonia. This enzymatic activity is crucial for the survival of H. pylori in the acidic environment of the stomach. By producing ammonia, H. pylori can neutralize the acidity around it, creating a more hospitable environment for itself and contributing to its pathogenicity, which is associated with gastric ulcers and chronic gastritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella does not produce urease and is known for causing foodborne illnesses primarily affecting the intestinal tract.

 

Option C. Escherichia coli: Incorrect, while some strains of E. coli can produce urease, it is not a characteristic feature, and they are primarily known for other virulence factors.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella does not produce urease and is known for causing dysentery or shigellosis through invasion and inflammation of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urease-producing organisms: (Mnemonic-PUNCH)

 

  • Proteus
  • asma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus, Corynebacterium urealyticum
  •  H. pylori

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

 

Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect, as macrolides are effective against Mycoplasma. They work by inhibiting protein synthesis and are commonly used to treat infections caused by these bacteria.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Incorrect, tetracyclines are also effective against Mycoplasma and work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Fluoroquinolones: Incorrect, fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis, are effective against a broad range of bacteria, including Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

choices.text: 73 degree Celsius for 20 minutes
63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes
72 degree Celsius for 30 seconds
63 degree Celsius for 30 seconds

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 63 degree Celsius for 30 minutes

 

Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either

 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15-20 seconds: the flash process

 

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

 

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pasteurization can be conducted using different time-temperature combinations, primarily the Holder method (63°C for 30 minutes) and the flash pasteurization method (72°C for 15-20 seconds), each designed to ensure the safety of milk consumption while preserving its quality.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod-human transmission route? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Japanese encephalitis

 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission.

 

JE virus infects several extra-human hosts, e.g., pigs and birds (like pond herons). The basic cycles of transmission are:

 

(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig

(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

 

Humans are incidental "dead-end" hosts and are infected by the bite of infected Culex mosquitoes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malaria: Caused by Plasmodium parasites, transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes, primarily involves a human-mosquito-human cycle without bird involvement.

 

Option C. Plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, typically involves rodents and fleas in its transmission cycle; humans are incidental hosts.

 

Option D. Paragonimiasis: Caused by Paragonimus worms, involves a cycle between snails, crabs/crayfish, and mammals (including humans), but not birds or typical arthropods like mosquitoes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The transmission cycles of diseases like Japanese encephalitis is crucial for implementing effective public health measures. In the case of JE, controlling mosquito populations and minimizing human exposure to mosquito bites, especially in areas where birds are present, are key strategies in preventing the disease.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Togavirus

 

Rubella belongs to the Togaviridae family.

 

Rubella (German measles)

 

  • Causative organism belongs to family Togaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks
  • Rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post infectious thrombocytopenia
  • Most serious complication: Encephalitis
  • Vaccination: 27/3 live attenuated

 

Congenital rubella syndrome:

 

  • When a woman in the 1st trimester gets infected with rubella, the resulting complications may include miscarriage, fetal death, premature delivery, or live birth with congenital defects.
  • The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataract, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome.
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term "blueberry muffin syndrome."

 

Expanded rubella syndrome:

 

  • Some babies present with several other features like hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions constituting the expanded rubella syndrome.
  • This term also refers to a baby with metastatic neuroblastoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flavivirus: This group includes viruses like the West Nile virus and Dengue virus, not Rubella.

 

Option C. Paramyxovirus: Includes viruses like measles and mumps, which are clinically distinct from rubella.

 

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: This is the family of viruses that includes the influenza viruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rubella, commonly known as German measles, is caused by a virus that belongs to the Togaviridae family, specifically the genus Rubivirus. This virus is typically transmitted via respiratory droplets and primarily causes a mild infection characterized by a rash, low fever, and swollen glands. However, its most significant health impact occurs when a pregnant woman is infected, particularly in the first trimester, leading to congenital rubella syndrome.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
﻿﻿﻿Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

 

This statement is incorrect because it is the female mite, not the male, that burrows into the skin. The male mites mainly stay on the surface of the skin and do not create burrows like the females do.

 

The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

 

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

 

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months. 

 

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

 

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Life history has 4 stages: The lifecycle of Sarcoptes scabiei consists of the egg, larva, nymph, and adult stages, correctly described in the statement.

 

Option B. Larvae have 3 pairs of legs: The larvae of the scabies mite indeed have three pairs of legs, distinguishing them from the adult mites.

 

Option C. The entire life cycle takes about 15 days: The lifecycle from egg to mature mite, under ideal conditions, typically spans around 15 days, making this statement accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The female Sarcoptes scabiei mite is responsible for burrowing into the skin and laying eggs, which leads to the intense itching and characteristic rash seen in scabies. Recognizing the specific behavior of the female mite in the transmission and lifecycle of scabies is crucial for effective diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysticercosis cellulose

 

The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosis cellulose.

 

Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.

 

The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Epilepsy
  • ﻿﻿Increased intracranial tension
  • ﻿﻿Hydrocephalus
  • ﻿﻿Psychiatric disturbances
  • ﻿﻿Meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿Transient paresis
  • ﻿﻿Behavioral disorders
  • ﻿﻿Aphasia
  • ﻿﻿Visual disturbances.

 

The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Scolex within a cyst
  • ﻿﻿Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement
  • ﻿﻿Nodular calcifications
  • ﻿﻿Focal enhancing lesions
  • ﻿﻿Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.

 

Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.

 

Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days after the institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions to dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. T. saginata: Incorrect. Known as the beef tapeworm, it does not typically lead to cysticercosis as its larvae (Cysticercus bovis) primarily infect cattle.

 

Option C. Cysticercosis bovis: Incorrect. This term is not applicable to human disease and refers to the larval stage of T. saginata found in cattle.

 

Option D. T. asiatica: Incorrect. This is a species of tapeworm similar to T. saginata and is associated with pigs, but like T. saginata, it is not commonly linked to neurocysticercosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurocysticercosis is identified with imaging studies, particularly in patients presenting with new-onset seizures and specific MRI findings of cystic lesions with scolex, is critical for timely diagnosis and appropriate management, including antiparasitic and supportive therapy.

questions.text: Vaccine that requires strain change due to evolving organism is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Influenza

 

 

The influenza vaccine is unique among vaccines because it requires periodic updates or strain changes almost every year. This necessity is due to the evolving nature of the influenza virus, particularly the frequent antigenic changes in its surface glycoproteins (hemagglutinin and neuraminidase). These changes can occur through two primary mechanisms:

 

  • Antigenic Drift: Minor changes that occur gradually over time as the virus replicates. These small genetic mutations can alter the antigenic properties of the virus, necessitating updates to the vaccine to maintain its effectiveness.
  • Antigenic Shift: Less frequent but more significant changes that can lead to the emergence of a completely new influenza virus subtype. This can potentially lead to pandemics if the new subtype spreads widely and the population has little to no immunity against it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diphtheria: The vaccine for diphtheria does not require frequent updates or strain changes. The causative bacterium (Corynebacterium diphtheriae) does not exhibit the same level of antigenic variation that necessitates vaccine modification.

 

Option C. Polio: Polio vaccines target stable viral antigens of the poliovirus, which do not undergo frequent antigenic changes, thus not requiring periodic strain updates.

 

Option D. Typhoid: Typhoid vaccines, such as those for Salmonella Typhi, also do not require frequent changes in formulation, as the bacterial antigens are relatively stable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The influenza vaccine must be updated regularly to match the antigenically evolving influenza virus strains, primarily due to antigenic drift (gradual) and shift (drastic). This adaptation is essential to enhance vaccine effectiveness and control the spread of flu each season, highlighting the dynamic challenge of influenza virus surveillance and vaccine formulation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was suffering from low grade fever, inspiratory stridor and barking cough for past 5 days. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the cause of this condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parainfluenza

 

Barking cough is a feature of laryngotracheobronchitis, which is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The X-ray finding is the 'Steeple sign' due to subglottic narrowing.

 

The age of presentation of laryngotracheobronchitis ranges from 6 months-6 years. The clinical features include barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever.

 

Management:

 

  • ﻿﻿Racemic epinephrine nebulization leads to the rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction.
  • Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
  • ﻿﻿Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>|V>|M). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
  • ﻿﻿Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (Sp02 <92 %)

 

Antibiotics are not indicated in laryngotracheobronchitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Moraxella: More commonly associated with conditions like otitis media and sinusitis rather than croup.

 

Option C. Haemophilus influenzae: Although capable of causing respiratory tract infections, it is not a typical cause of croup.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus: Known for more severe respiratory conditions like bacterial tracheitis, which is distinct from viral croup and presents with more severe symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parainfluenza is a common cause of croup. The 'Steeple sign' on X-ray supports this diagnosis, emphasizing the need for prompt and effective treatment to ensure rapid recovery and prevent complications.

choices.text: Nipah virus

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism category A agent? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthrax

 

Anthrax, caused by Bacillus anthracis, is classified as a Category A bioterrorism agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Category A agents are those deemed highest risk for use in bioterrorism due to their ease of dissemination or transmission and their high potential for significant public health impact, resulting in high mortality rates and the potential for major public health impact.

 

  • Characteristics of Anthrax:
    • Transmission: Can occur through cutaneous, inhalational, or gastrointestinal exposure to spore-forming bacteria.
    • Impact: Especially deadly in its inhalational form, anthrax can cause severe respiratory issues, shock, and often death if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nipah virus: It is not classified as a category A agent. It is a zoonotic virus that can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis, primarily in Southeast Asia.

 

Option C. Coxiella: The bacterium that causes Q fever, is not classified as a category A agent. Q fever is typically acquired from infected animals or their products.

 

Option D. Brucella: It causes brucellosis, zoonotic infection primarily transmitted through contact with infected animals or consumption of contaminated animal products.

 

Educational Objective

 

Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

 

Other category A agents are:

 

  • Botulism (Clostridium botulinum toxin)
  • Plague (Yersinia pestis)
  • Smallpox (Variola virus)
  • Tularemia (Francisella tularensis) - Francisella tularensis bacteria cause tularemia, also known as rabbit fever.
